name: Magnesia sulphurica
Relationship: It is claimed that the addition of a small amount of MAGNES. SULPH. to the usual hypodermic of Morphine increases the value of the hypodermic from 50 to 100%.

Head: Apprehensive; vertigo; head heavy during menses
Eyes burn, noises in ears
Fever: Chill from 9 to ten am shuddering in back; heat in one part and chill in another
Stomach: Frequent eructations, tasting like bad eggs
Urine: The urine passed in the morning copious, bright yellow, soon becomes turbid, and deposits a copious red sediment
The urine is greenish as passed; is of a clear color, and in a large quantity
Stitches and burning the orifice of the urethra after urinating
Back: Violent pain in the small of the back, as if bruised, and as before menstruation
Bruised and ulcerative pain between the shoulders, with a feeling as of a lump as large as the fist, on which account she could not lie upon her back or side; relieved by rubbing
Female: Some blood from the vagina between the menses
Menstruation returned after fourteen days; the discharge was thick, black, and profuse
Thick leucorrhoea, as profuse as the menses, with weary pain in the small of the back and thighs, on moving about
Skin: Crawling in the tips of the fingers of the left hand; better on rubbing
Small pimples over the whole body, that itch violently
Extremities: The left arm and foot fall asleep in bed, in the morning after waking

dosage: The pure salt to the third potency. Locally 1:4 in water in septic conditions, erysipelas, orchitis, boils, etc.Epsom salts is one of the most active saline cathartics, operating with little pain or nausea, especially if pure. It has but little if any effect on intestinal peristalsis, its action causing a rush of fluid into the intestine, which by producing a distention of the bowel produces evacuation. It causes little or no irritation in the intestine. In common with the other salines, it is the classical evacuant to be employed in connection with mercurials and anthelmintics and in cases of poisoning. Epsom salt usually acts within from one to two hours, more quickly if taken in hot water and in the morning before breakfast. The ordinary dose as a mild laxative is a heaping teaspoonful; as a cathartic, two to four teaspoonfuls. The taste may be improved, if necessary, by the addition of a little lemon juice and sugar.Magnes. Sulph. is of diagnostic and therapeutic value in Gallstone colic. From 2 to 4 teaspoonfuls in glass hot water taken at onset of a colicky attack may abort or stop the colic.Besides its chief use as a saline cathartic, magnesium sulphate is used to a considerable extent externally in saturated solution as an antiphlogistic and antipruritic in erysipelas, ivy poisoning, cellulitis and other local inflammations. Use on compresses saturated with solution.
